snippet.textDisplay: I have a Colorado LTZ and love it. The only downside is the lack of adjustable lumber support in the drivers seat. I have an old hip and upper thigh injury, and if I drive for more than an hour, I struggle to walk for about 10 minutes after I get out. I thought it was just me, but I have since found out a number of other drivers complain about the exact same thing. An after market seat is now on my shopping list.  As for the interior, I don't find it looking very plastic at all. I think it is nice and well laid out. I have not towed my boat with it yet (3,200kg) so that will be interesting.
snippet.textOriginal: I have a Colorado LTZ and love it. The only downside is the lack of adjustable lumber support in the drivers seat. I thought it was just me, but I have since found out a number of other drivers complain about the exact same thing. An after market seat is now on my shopping list.  As for the interior, I don't find it looking very plastic at all. I think it is nice and well laid out. I have not towed my boat with it yet (3,200kg) so that will be interesting.

snippet.textDisplay: After test driving a few utes we bought the Triton and have to say really impressed with it. comfy, quiet and  good at towing a large trailer and now i know you can get a tune to lose a bit of the turbo lag (which i will be doing) i am really impressed with the vehical. Have not done as much 4x4 yet as have a bashed jeep that i use, so i dont scratch me new ute but will be using more as the jeep needs to go to a new home but do love the turbo diesel in the jeep but the Triton seems to have been a good upgrde so far. Great vid cheers for doing this as all you see on the net is the Triton is crap and people laugh when you say you have one and a good and honest no holding back test like you guys do everytime just shows how wrong peopel can be. nice one guys.

snippet.textDisplay:
I like comparison tests like this. I honestly thought that the Hilux would be the winner. That rear bed/tub design of the Triton /L200 in relation to its rear wheel is just asking for chassis issues down the line. That clearly can't be called good design and engineering. Looks more like function following form. The old Mitsubishis were much more rugged and better. So considering all, my choice winner would be the Hilux. But the one I would buy would be the Mazda.
Since this was a test about diesel engined trucks, I guess the Ram 1500 was not a real contender. But if we were talking about the Ram 2500, then you'd see real power. Patriot Campers has certainly proved that those RAMs are solid with that SuperTourer of theirs'. Would like to see one of those featured on the show. Even the Ram 1500, since 4wd Action has featured LS swapped Patrols. How about it?
snippet.textOriginal:

Looks more like function following form. The old Mitsubishis were much more rugged and better. So considering all, my choice winner would be the  Hilux. But the one I would buy would be the Mazda. 
Since this was a test about diesel engined trucks, I guess the Ram 1500 was not a real contender. But if we were talking about the Ram 2500, then you'd see real power. snippet.textDisplay: Great review and tips, just saying I drive allot vehicles and never going to buy a Mitsi over a Toyota, just not a Mitsi person, yes I have driven Tritons, not a fan of these smaller engines either, having drive Ranger WTs and the 3.2 WT does not impress me at all (BiTurbo) jerky laggy, maybe the tunes but 3 seperate ones all the same,  agree with buying base models and doing the right upgrades, had 2 SR5s D4D N70s,  manual and auto and my biggest mistake was buying SR5 over a std model for price and doing the right mods, I’ll also never own a VW again ever! Dmax always enjoyed driving them, maybe I just like a real truck feel not all the fancy distraction BS in modern vehicles, I still think many of these utes are overpriced today though, thanks for the real world test it was awesome and your experts on point, can’t cover ever model of every year, so base that on 2020 models in test. a good work team. Now get a real 4wd, go the 80. 🤙

snippet.textDisplay:
Great review guys.
I recently purchased a new dual cab after test driving and researching most of the above mentioned utes. I did feel the Mitsubishi to be the most honest and best bang for buck. My only disagree with this review was the comfort you guys mentioned. The Mitsy (although no where near as harsh as the D'max) felt almost old-school dual cab on the road for comfort compared to some of the others. And when I say comfort I mean how the ute handled bumps on the road. After test driving the Triton, vehicles like the Ranger, NP300 felt like a car in comparison.
Anyone else's opinion on this?
snippet.textOriginal:
Great review guys.  
I recently purchased a new dual cab  after test driving and researching most of the above mentioned utes.  I did feel the Mitsubishi to be the most honest and best bang for buck.  My only disagree with this review was the comfort you guys mentioned. The Mitsy (although no where near as harsh as the D'max) felt almost old-school dual cab on the road for comfort compared to some of the others.  And when I say comfort I mean how the ute handled bumps on the road.   After test driving the Triton, vehicles like the Ranger, NP300 felt like a car in comparison.   
Anyone else's opinion on this?

snippet.textDisplay:
1 thing I’ll never understand is the whole “Hilux resale” thing.
Why in the world is a Ute that’s so basic, drives rough as guts and has had huge reliability problems, known for its resale 😂
It’s a 45k Ute with a 55k price tag.
They used to be bullet proof 7 years ago but I don’t see how people are still brainwashed all these years later. The Hilux is a dud compared to the others

snippet.textDisplay: Great to have some 4WD guys doing some real world testing on the machinery we all use. Interesting that you have made subjective opinions on certain vehicles and they have skewed the numbers in the results. The Nissan Navara gets penalised for 'the D40 transmission issues' where the transmission guy would need more years trouble free before he would be happy (although no issues with the current crop of transmissions) yet no weighting is given to the significant issues with the previous generation Triton  engine upper engine carbon build ups or to the Hilux and the significant 'limp' issues that occur when driving in heavy dust environments (previous reviews have mentioned this in test as a safety issue which as of now still has no fix (including the newest updates of the Fortuner, Hilux and Prado airboxs). Also of note is that you compare value and move down from the Colorado and the Ranger to the second top models, yet still compare the top specs in other models. Not sure how that presents as a 'fair and level's playing field. The same about the Navara engine which like the Isuzu engine, has been in service in Europe for well over a decade in Renault etc without any issues. The Nissan may require upper control arms as part of a suspension upgrade but you have failed to take into account that a full suspension upgrade for a Navara is cheaper as it is all coil and not leaves, making it cost neutral. There are more questions but overall it is great to have an 'independent' assesment of the major players in the Australian dual cab sphere.
snippet.textOriginal: Great to have some 4WD guys doing some real world testing on the machinery we all use. Interesting that you have made subjective opinions on certain vehicles and they have skewed the numbers in the results. The Nissan Navara gets penalised for 'the D40 transmission issues' where the transmission guy would need more years trouble free before he would be happy (although no issues with the current crop of transmissions) yet no weighting is given to the significant issues with the previous generation Triton  engine upper engine carbon build ups or to the Hilux and the significant 'limp' issues that occur when driving in heavy dust environments (previous reviews have mentioned this in test as a safety issue which as of now still has no fix (including the newest updates of the Fortuner, Hilux and Prado airboxs). Also of note is that you compare value and move down from the Colorado and the Ranger to the second top models, yet still compare the top specs in other models. Not sure how that presents as a 'fair and level's playing field. The same about the Navara engine which like the Isuzu engine, has been in service in Europe for well over a decade in Renault etc without any issues. The Nissan may require upper control arms as part of a suspension upgrade but you have failed to take into account that a full suspension upgrade for a Navara is cheaper as it is all coil and not leaves, making it cost neutral. There are more questions but overall it is great to have an 'independent' assesment of the major players in the Australian dual cab sphere.

snippet.textDisplay: I own a Ford Wildtrack and have put 41K Km on it over the 5 years I have owned it.  It drives and runs very well and I have no issues.  What I have seen about all of these trucks, I would trust those who know a little about building tough trucks.  Toyota, Ford/Mazda, and GM to me have that know how.  I saw an overlanding trip in Western Australia and a Isuzu twisted off a wheel and axle!  I have a friend that drove a mitsubishi suv and had the front end literally fall out after a few years of driving it over the pot holed streets of Thailand.  Nissan produces great cars and engines but they do not know pickups like the American companies and VW will produce a great truck someday when they put in the research, but not today.  I liked this head to  head competition but to really know how these trucks last, more statistics will need to be gathered.  The testers being from after market power systems, transmissions, and other related industries that support 4wheeling are really helpful.  I would love to see a long term testing of all of these vehicles.  Thanks for a well thought out test.
snippet.textOriginal: I own a Ford Wildtrack and have put 41K Km on it over the 5 years I have owned it.  It drives and runs very well and I have no issues.  What I have seen about all of these trucks, I would trust those who know a little about building tough trucks.  Toyota, Ford/Mazda, and GM to me have that know how.  I saw an overlanding trip in Western Australia and a Isuzu twisted off a wheel and axle!  I have a friend that drove a mitsubishi suv and had the front end literally fall out after a few years of driving it over the pot holed streets of Thailand.  Nissan produces great cars and engines but they do not know pickups like the American companies and VW will produce a great truck someday when they put in the research, but not today.  I liked this head to  head competition but to really know how these trucks last, more statistics will need to be gathered.  The testers being from after market power systems, transmissions, and other related industries that support 4wheeling are really helpful.  I would love to see a long term testing of all of these vehicles.  Thanks for a well thought out test.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thanks a lot for one of the first serious reviews I have seen. A big thumbs up for all the brands for give them the trucks even knowing Shauno is going to be there 🤣. Same tires on all was a fine touch. Some interesting things came up. The Triton (L200 for us) is doing right things everywhere, Amaronk really need a low range it they really want to get serious, Isuzu as reliable as usual, Nissan need to remember the 720 and D21 and get rid of the Renault influence if want to keep up, Mazda need to get out of the Ford partnership to release their BT50 from being a shadow of the Ranger (I think they are in the process), the Ranger is a good one with the 3.2 but will discard totally the eco blown tiny engine. Holden, well is a Isuzu in a bad day. And confirming why Hilux is the sales leader. The truck don’t go for the top numbers on any specific part but have consistently good rank on all them and that’s why it is the more balanced and offers the best average and that’s what the intelligent buyers are looking for.
I love Toyota but also Mitsubishi and will stay on the Triton side this time. Great job!!
snippet.textOriginal:

The truck don’t go for the top numbers on any specific part but have consistently good rank on all them and that’s why it is the more balanced and offers the best average and that’s what the intelligent buyers are looking for.
I love Toyota but also Mitsubishi and will stay on the Triton side this time. Great job!!

snippet.textDisplay:
Does the triton come with the super select system in Australia?
I believe there are 'super select' versions in Europe. That would give you the benefit of a lockable middle diff and the ability to drive 4x4 on tarmac (with the diff open).

Driving a Hilux Vigo myself (and happy with it, was also the cheapest option giving our werid tax regulation system in the Netherlands).
snippet.textOriginal:

Driving a Hilux Vigo myself (and happy with it, was also the cheapest option giving our werid tax regulation system in the Netherlands).

snippet.textDisplay: 2007 ML with nearly 300K on the dial. Been Kimberleys, Pilbara, WA goldfields, crossed Nullarbor, 100’s SW beaches. Old Man Emu and BFG shoes. Zero dramas. Biggest issue is the paint! Sunburnt and peeling. Other than that, cannot recommend them enough. Get out and explore this place, best on earth.
snippet.textOriginal: 2007 ML with nearly 300K on the dial. Been Kimberleys, Pilbara, WA goldfields, crossed Nullarbor, 100’s SW beaches. Old Man Emu and BFG shoes. Zero dramas. Biggest issue is the paint! Sunburnt and peeling. Other than that, cannot recommend them enough. Get out and explore this place, best on earth.

snippet.textDisplay: I have the early model colorado (2010) and quickly found the use of handbrake to overcome the lack of diff lock an absolute treat. Which is good as I tow every day

Loved this test! The missing low range box on the Amarok really disappointed me when I had one to test out.
It's not only off-road where it is missing a gear. For me it was particularly obvious when I tried maneuvering a heavy trailer uphill, where it did not take long for the otherwise awesome 8 speed to overheat.

snippet.textDisplay: This would have to the most comprehensive "real world" ute comparison I've come across. Well done guys. I have an MY14 D'Max LSM and have done 212K km including towing just on 3 tonne as a full time nomad. Other than usual maintenance,  the only "failure" of any sort was a transfer case extension seal setting me back $9.95 at 130K km. Basic, old school, truck like (love that)  but simply a work horse you can trust. Love that little 4jj1 truck engine.
snippet.textOriginal: This would have to the most comprehensive "real world" ute comparison I've come across. Well done guys. I have an MY14 D'Max LSM and have done 212K km including towing just on 3 tonne as a full time nomad. Other than usual maintenance,  the only "failure" of any sort was a transfer case extension seal setting me back $9.95 at 130K km. Basic, old school, truck like (love that)  but simply a work horse you can trust. Love that little 4jj1 truck engine.

snippet.textDisplay:
I own a 2006 Gu Patrol tb48 and have been looking at buying a dual cab to have beside the trusty old patrol.

With our family of 4x we have done a few big trips in the patrol wagon and our method of camping with the oztent rv5 and living out of the patrol with no trailer we've been finding we need more room.

With all my research I had pretty much decided on the dmax or the triton so I'm glad your very detailed excellent video backed that up! I might wait until the 2020 dmax comes out and get that one with the rear locker and new features.

Our plan is to chuck an alloy tray and canopy on the dual cab and set it up for touring and keep the trusty old patrol for the tough stuff on the weekends cheers fellas love your work!
snippet.textOriginal:
I own a 2006 Gu Patrol tb48 and have been looking at buying a dual cab to have beside the trusty old patrol. 

With our family of 4x we have done a few big trips in the patrol wagon and our method of camping with the oztent rv5 and living out of the patrol with no trailer we've been finding we need more room. 

With all my research I had pretty much decided on the dmax or the triton so I'm glad your very detailed excellent video backed that up! I might wait until the 2020 dmax comes out and get that one with the rear locker and new features. 

Our plan is to chuck an alloy tray and canopy on the dual cab and set it up for touring and keep the trusty old patrol for the tough stuff on the weekends cheers fellas love your work!

snippet.textDisplay: I have an amarok tdi580 and I honestly can't fault it on or off road. It went over massive obstacles on 20" road tyres and performed as well as a kitted up ranger and Hilux. I found the traction control system amazing when wheels were off the ground and the 580nm to me more than makes up for not having low range. Clearance and the low air intake are my biggest weaknesses thus far.
snippet.textOriginal: I have an amarok tdi580 and I honestly can't fault it on or off road. It went over massive obstacles on 20" road tyres and performed as well as a kitted up ranger and Hilux. I found the traction control system amazing when wheels were off the ground and the 580nm to me more than makes up for not having low range. Clearance and the low air intake are my biggest weaknesses thus far.

snippet.textDisplay: Great job guys, a real 4WD test at last.  For the record I own a Nissan Navara and installed a $300 IDrive and fixed the engine issue.  OME suspension was also a game changer.
snippet.textOriginal: Great job guys, a real 4WD test at last.  For the record I own a Nissan Navara and installed a $300 IDrive and fixed the engine issue.  OME suspension was also a game changer.

snippet.textDisplay: This is biased! How can you compare the Colorado transmission to the Ranger which clearly has problems. You rate them the same!  The Colorado actually has higher NM of torque and it can tow more. The auto manual transmission is brilliant and locks in gear very well when required. Mine has an actual 1 ton rated capacity and it can and does tow 3500kg easily. Indeed it actually is a far better tow vehicle than my old Landcruiser wagon. So far it has travelled over 100,000k no issues. Interesting test but sadly biased. The fact is the Colorado can tow more than the Hilux unless you opt for the primitive manual transmission. But again the vehicle weighs less and so actually can tow less. I have after loving the cruisers seriously considered the Hi Lux but sadly it is still a less capable vehicle for heavy towing which is what I require. Your point about transmission coolers is very valid. They all should have them. The Ranger has a nice interior but stupid high bonnet which restricts vision. Low range is essential. Colorado can be ordered with 600nms although I think you would be mad to do so!
snippet.textOriginal: This is biased! How can you compare the Colorado transmission to the Ranger which clearly has problems. You rate them the same!  The Colorado actually has higher NM of torque and it can tow more. The auto manual transmission is brilliant and locks in gear very well when required. Mine has an actual 1 ton rated capacity and it can and does tow 3500kg easily. Indeed it actually is a far better tow vehicle than my old Landcruiser wagon. So far it has travelled over 100,000k no issues. Interesting test but sadly biased. The fact is the Colorado can tow more than the Hilux unless you opt for the primitive manual transmission. But again the vehicle weighs less and so actually can tow less. I have after loving the cruisers seriously considered the Hi Lux but sadly it is still a less capable vehicle for heavy towing which is what I require. Your point about transmission coolers is very valid. They all should have them. The Ranger has a nice interior but stupid high bonnet which restricts vision. Low range is essential. Colorado can be ordered with 600nms although I think you would be mad to do so!

Hate to say it, but NONE of those cars are made for true 4WD off road driving.

They are just to modern, new, luxury, electronic, tradesman, construction industry, shiny and made for the road. None of those cars suite off road driving, they looked like a Ferrari going mudding. It just doesnt look right.

Real 4wd's are Jeeps,land cruisers and range rovers. Just solid rigs.

snippet.textDisplay: Loved this real world comparison! No other so called automotive "journalist" would know and tell you anything that even comes close!! Kudos! Loved it! I thought mitusbishi had lost its true 4x4 roots by looking at its out dated pajero. But looking at this.. we can know so much more! Transmission with cooler, hieght adjustment, price point! 👍Loved this comparison 🙂

snippet.textDisplay: Just to add some info that you may be interested in, if you buy one new and you are getting Finance, choose what you want to add , bull bar, 2 inch lift, lockers etc. get a quote from various aftermarket installers. Go back to the dealer get them to add in the cost of your add ons into your finance. They will give you a cheque to pay for the add ons. This way you save paying 30% for luxury tax when getting items fitted in the factory.
snippet.textOriginal: Just to add some info that you may be interested in, if you buy one new and you are getting Finance, choose what you want to add , bull bar, 2 inch lift, lockers etc. get a quote from various aftermarket installers. Go back to the dealer get them to add in the cost of your add ons into your finance. They will give you a cheque to pay for the add ons. This way you save paying 30% for luxury tax when getting items fitted in the factory.

snippet.textDisplay: Would have been nice to also include an old standard vehicle to see how they compare with todays vehicles. I've a stock 79 series ute with a nat asp 1HZ (not the big fancy V8). Putting something like that up against these new smaller, higher powered common rail engines would be interesting.

snippet.textDisplay: Good video, not the normal type where it’s all about peak power on paper. I have a MY18 Hilux and love it, comfortable seats, easy to use  right down to the window switches. The led headlights are outstanding for night driving not feeling fatigued, add that into the mix - night driving, can your understand the dash read outs ect at day and night..
snippet.textOriginal: Good video, not the normal type where it’s all about peak power on paper. I have a MY18 Hilux and love it, comfortable seats, easy to use  right down to the window switches. snippet.textDisplay:
Let's be honest for a second here most of these cars a brought by either tradies or people trying to brush there ego.
I'm a Truckie and to be brutally honest some of the stupid shit I see from over loading to complete and utter disregard for anyone who sits in a lower car is pathetic.
Now I'm not saying everyone but some people pull your head in just because u have a bullbar and a lift kit doesn't make u invisible.
